verses.text: Then Pilate took Jesus and had Him flogged.
verses.comment: Flogging was the typical Roman method of preparing a condemned man for crucifixion. Note the fulfillment of Isaiah 53:5 ('by His wounds we are healed'), as Jesus bears the punishment for sin.

verses.text: And the soldiers twisted together a crown of thorns and put it on His head, and dressed Him in a purple robe.
verses.comment: The crown of thorns is both mockery and profound symbolism, signifying the curse of sin (Genesis 3:18) placed on Christ.

verses.text: They came up to Him, saying, “Hail, King of the Jews!” and struck Him with their hands.
verses.comment: Here Jesus is mocked as a king, yet His true kingship is revealed through His suffering.

verses.text: Pilate went out again and said to them, 'Look, I am bringing Him out to you, so that you may know that I find no guilt in Him.'
verses.comment: Pilate’s declaration of Jesus’ innocence underscores His role as the spotless sacrificial Lamb (Exodus 12:5; 1 Peter 1:19).

verses.text: So Jesus came out, wearing the crown of thorns and the purple robe. And Pilate said to them, 'Behold the man!'
verses.comment: 'Behold the man!' can be taken as a reference to Zechariah 6:12 and Daniel 7:13, with messianic undertones. Jesus is presented publicly as the true King and Son of Man.

verses.text: When the chief priests and officers saw Him, they cried out, “Crucify, crucify!” Pilate said to them, “Take Him yourselves and crucify Him, for I find no guilt in Him.”
verses.comment: Once again Jesus is declared innocent, fulfilling the imagery of the innocent Passover Lamb. The leaders’ demand implicates all humanity in Christ’s death.

verses.text: The Jews answered him, “We have a law, and according to that law He ought to die because He made Himself the Son of God.”
verses.comment: Calling Himself the Son of God is, in the context, a claim to divinity (John 5:18), which the law of Moses considers blasphemy (Leviticus 24:16).

verses.text: When Pilate heard this statement, he was even more afraid.
verses.comment: Pilate’s fear likely comes from both the supernatural claims about Jesus and his wife’s dream (see Matthew 27:19).

verses.text: He went back into the headquarters and said to Jesus, 'Where are You from?' But Jesus gave him no answer.
verses.comment: Jesus’ silence fulfills Isaiah 53:7 ('He opened not his mouth'), signifying His submission to the Father's will.

verses.text: So Pilate said to Him, 'Do You not speak to me? Do You not know that I have authority to release You and authority to crucify You?'
verses.comment: Pilate asserts his earthly authority. But ultimate authority over Jesus’ fate lies not with Pilate but with God.

verses.text: Jesus answered him, 'You would have no authority over Me at all unless it had been given to you from above. Therefore he who delivered Me over to you has the greater sin.'
verses.comment: Earthly authority is permitted by God (see Romans 13:1); Jesus acknowledges divine sovereignty, and He distinguishes the greater sin of betrayal.

verses.text: From then on Pilate sought to release Him, but the Jews cried out, 'If you release this man, you are no friend of Caesar. Everyone who makes himself a king opposes Caesar.'
verses.comment: Political pressure from the religious leaders manipulates Pilate, emphasizing the conflict between earthly and heavenly allegiance.

verses.text: So when Pilate heard these words, he brought Jesus out and sat down on the judgment seat at a place called The Stone Pavement, in Aramaic, Gabbatha.
verses.comment: Gabbatha is a stone-paved place used for official judgment. The setting highlights the formality and gravity of the judgment.

verses.text: Now it was the day of Preparation of the Passover. It was about the sixth hour. He said to the Jews, 'Behold your King!'
verses.comment: Jesus is presented as King at the same time the Passover lambs were being prepared, further linking Him with the Lamb of God (see Exodus 12).

verses.text: They cried out, 'Away with Him! Away with Him! Crucify Him!' Pilate said to them, 'Shall I crucify your King?' The chief priests answered, 'We have no king but Caesar.'
verses.comment: The chief priests' declaration is a profound rejection of God as their King (1 Samuel 8:7) and a tragic embrace of earthly authority.

verses.text: So he delivered Him over to them to be crucified. So they took Jesus,
verses.comment: Jesus is handed over to death, showing His voluntary acceptance of the Father's salvific plan.

verses.text: and He went out, bearing His own cross, to the place called The Place of a Skull, which in Aramaic is called Golgotha.
verses.comment: Bearing His own cross signifies Jesus’ total submission and echoes Isaac carrying the wood for his own sacrifice (Genesis 22:6).

verses.text: There they crucified Him, and with Him two others, one on either side, and Jesus between them.
verses.comment: Jesus is numbered among the transgressors (Isaiah 53:12), fulfilling prophecy.

verses.text: Pilate also wrote an inscription and put it on the cross. It read, 'Jesus of Nazareth, the King of the Jews.'
verses.comment: The titulus defines Jesus’ true identity and kingship, even in death.

verses.text: Many of the Jews read this inscription, for the place where Jesus was crucified was near the city, and it was written in Aramaic, Latin, and Greek.
verses.comment: Written in three languages, the proclamation is for all peoples: the universality of Christ's kingship is revealed.

verses.text: So the chief priests of the Jews said to Pilate, 'Do not write
verses.comment: The chief priests attempt to control the narrative, but Pilate’s wording stands firm, highlighting Jesus' royal status.

verses.text: Pilate answered, 'What I have written I have written.'
verses.comment: Pilate’s stubbornness unintentionally affirms the divine kingship of Jesus for all to see.

verses.text: When the soldiers had crucified Jesus, they took His garments and divided them into four parts, one part for each soldier; also His tunic. But the tunic was seamless, woven in one piece from top to bottom.
verses.comment: Jesus’ seamless tunic is a subtle image of priestly unity and fulfills Psalm 22:18, where lots are cast for the Messiah’s clothing.

verses.text: So they said to one another, 'Let us not tear it, but cast lots for it to see whose it shall be.' This was to fulfill the Scripture which says, 'They divided my garments among them, and for my clothing they cast lots.' So the soldiers did these things.
verses.comment: Direct fulfillment of Messianic prophecy reinforces the divine plan at work, even in small details.

verses.text: But standing by the cross of Jesus were His mother, and His mother’s sister, Mary the wife of Clopas, and Mary Magdalene.
verses.comment: The steadfast presence of Jesus’ mother highlights her unique role and faithfulness at the hour of redemption.

verses.text: When Jesus saw His mother and the disciple whom He loved standing nearby, He said to His mother, 'Woman, behold your son!'
verses.comment: Jesus entrusts Mary to John, indicating her maternal role in the community of believers. Spiritually, she is seen as mother to all disciples.

verses.text: Then He said to the disciple, 'Behold, your mother!' And from that hour the disciple took her into his own home.
verses.comment: John’s acceptance of Mary symbolizes the Church’s embrace of the blessed mother as spiritual mother — a theme echoed in later Christian tradition.

verses.text: After this, Jesus, knowing that all was now finished, said (to fulfill the Scripture), 'I thirst.'
verses.comment: Jesus fulfills prophecy (Psalm 69:21), and His thirst has both literal and spiritual resonance, echoing His offering of Himself.

verses.text: A jar full of sour wine stood there, so they put a sponge full of sour wine on a hyssop branch and held it to His mouth.
verses.comment: Hyssop was used to sprinkle the blood of the Passover lamb (Exodus 12:22), reinforcing Jesus as the true Paschal Lamb.

verses.text: When Jesus had received the sour wine, He said, 'It is finished,' and He bowed His head and gave up His spirit.
verses.comment: 'It is finished' means the completion of His redemptive mission, perfectly fulfilling the law and prophets. His voluntary surrender of 'His spirit' highlights His divine authority even in death.

verses.text: Since it was the day of Preparation, and so that the bodies would not remain on the cross on the Sabbath (for that Sabbath was a high day), the Jews asked Pilate that their legs might be broken and that they might be taken away.
verses.comment: Leaving bodies exposed during Sabbath violated the law (Deut. 21:22-23). The 'high day' underscores the sacred timing aligning with Passover symbolism.

verses.text: So the soldiers came and broke the legs of the first and of the other who had been crucified with Him.
verses.comment: Breaking the legs hastened death. Jesus’ death without broken bones fulfills Messianic prophecy.

verses.text: But when they came to Jesus and saw that He was already dead, they did not break His legs.
verses.comment: No broken bone (Exodus 12:46; Psalm 34:20) identifies Jesus as the true Passover Lamb.

verses.text: But one of the soldiers pierced His side with a spear, and at once there came out blood and water.
verses.comment: Blood and water symbolize sacramental outpouring and fulfillment of Zechariah 12:10. Many see this as signifying the streams of life flowing from Christ’s side to the whole Church.

verses.text: He who saw it has testified—his testimony is true, and he knows that he tells the truth—that you also may believe.
verses.comment: The eyewitness testimony underlines the historical reliability of these events, essential for faith.

verses.text: For these things took place that the Scripture might be fulfilled: 'Not one of His bones will be broken.'
verses.comment: Repetition of fulfillment reinforces Jesus as the anti-type to the Old Testament Passover Lamb.

verses.text: And again another Scripture says, 'They will look on Him whom they have pierced.'
verses.comment: Another prophetic allusion. This invites contemplation of the true identity of the Crucified One as Messiah and Lord.

verses.text: After these things, Joseph of Arimathea, who was a disciple of Jesus, but secretly for fear of the Jews, asked Pilate that he might take away the body of Jesus, and Pilate gave him permission. So he came and took away His body.
verses.comment: Joseph’s courageous act fulfills Isaiah 53:9 ('He was with a rich man in his death') and cares for Jesus’ body with dignity.

verses.text: Nicodemus also, who earlier had come to Jesus by night, came bringing a mixture of myrrh and aloes, about seventy-five pounds in weight.
verses.comment: Nicodemus’ offering is extravagant and points to the honor due the anointed King in burial.

verses.text: So they took the body of Jesus and bound it in linen cloths with the spices, as is the burial custom of the Jews.
verses.comment: Jesus’ burial is conducted with care and reverence, anticipating His resurrection and foreshadowing later Christian burial practice.

verses.text: Now in the place where He was crucified there was a garden, and in the garden a new tomb in which no one had yet been laid.
verses.comment: The new tomb emphasizes Jesus’ innocence and the fulfillment of Isaiah 53:9.

verses.text: So because of the Jewish day of Preparation, since the tomb was close at hand, they laid Jesus there.
verses.comment: The immediacy of burial was to observe Sabbath law, preserving Jesus’ body from dishonor.
